Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. This raises critical questions:ğŸ“Œ Does this reflect the real-world work environment?ğŸ“Œ Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?ğŸ“Œ Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?ğŸ” Evidence & Trends:âœ… AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.âœ… Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.âœ… Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineeringâ€”not just coding fluency.âš ï¸ The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that donâ€™t measure real-world capabilities.---ğŸŒ The Perfect Hiring Process â€“ If We Lived in a Perfect WorldğŸ”¹ ğŸ“ Intro Chat (30 min) â€“ A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?ğŸ’¬ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?ğŸ’¬ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.â†³ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.â†³ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.â†³ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.â†³ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.â†³ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.â€¢ â€¢ â€¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?ğŸ’¬ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

ğŸ’¡ 3 DevOps Lessons I Wish I Knew Earlier ğŸ’¡When I started my journey as a Cloud & DevOps Engineer, I thought mastering tools like Kubernetes, Terraform, and CI/CD was all I needed. But experience has taught me some valuable lessons that go beyond just the tech.Here are 3 key lessons I wish I knew earlier:ğŸ”¹ 1. Simplicity > ComplexityJust because you can deploy a fully automated multi-cluster Kubernetes setup doesnâ€™t mean you should. The best solutions are often the simplest ones that meet business needs.ğŸ”¹ 2. Automation is NOT a One-Time TaskBuilding a CI/CD pipeline or an infrastructure-as-code setup is greatâ€”but itâ€™s never "done." Things change, and continuous improvement is part of the DevOps mindset.ğŸ”¹ 3. Logs & Monitoring Save LivesNo matter how good your deployment strategy is, things will break. The key to quick recovery is good observabilityâ€”logs, metrics, and alerts (Grafana, Loki, Prometheus, etc.). If you canâ€™t see whatâ€™s happening, you canâ€™t fix it fast.Iâ€™ll be sharing more insights like this every week. ğŸŒŸ Pro Tip for Job Seekers! ğŸŒŸğŸš€ When hunting for your next role, remember, you don't have to check every box to be the perfect candidate! If you meet at least 70% of the qualifications, go ahead and apply! ğŸ¯ Many talented individuals self-disqualify, thinking they need to be a 100% match. That's not the case! I can testify!ğŸ’¡ At Microsoft, our managers, recruiters and hiring committees are trained to focus on candidates who align closely with most of the job requirements, not all. ğŸ“šğŸ‘€ğŸ› ï¸ As a seasoned IT professional who learned this the hard way early on in my IT career, I'm here to tell youâ€”give yourself a chance! Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.â†³ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.â†³ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.â†³ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.â†³ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.â†³ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.â€¢ â€¢ â€¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?ğŸ’¬ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

Simplicity > ComplexityJust because you can deploy a fully automated multi-cluster Kubernetes setup doesnâ€™t mean you should. The best solutions are often the simplest ones that meet business needs.ğŸ”¹ 2. Automation is NOT a One-Time TaskBuilding a CI/CD pipeline or an infrastructure-as-code setup is greatâ€”but itâ€™s never "done." Things change, and continuous improvement is part of the DevOps mindset.ğŸ”¹ 3. Logs & Monitoring Save LivesNo matter how good your deployment strategy is, things will break. The key to quick recovery is good observabilityâ€”logs, metrics, and alerts (Grafana, Loki, Prometheus, etc.). If you canâ€™t see whatâ€™s happening, you canâ€™t fix it fast.Iâ€™ll be sharing more insights like this every week. Letâ€™s connect and grow together! ğŸš€ğŸ‘‰ Whatâ€™s one DevOps lesson youâ€™ve learned the hard way? Drop a comment below!

Username: Petrina Frost, MBA (HR Mgt)Petrina Frost, MBA (HR Mgt)
Post Content:
Insights from LinkedIn Poll on Job Transition TimesI recently conducted a poll on LinkedIn to understand how long people typically expect to be between roles. The results were quite revealing and offer several insights into the current job market dynamics.A significant 37% of respondents indicated that their transition between roles was around 6 weeks. Meanwhile, 26% of participants reported a gap of around 3 months. This period could reflect the average time it takes for a thorough job search, including the application process and multiple rounds of interviews.Interestingly, 21% of respondents experienced a 6-month gap between roles. This longer duration might be attributed to more challenging job markets or specific industry requirements.Finally, 16% of those surveyed expressed feeling stuck on the bench and needing help. This emphasizes the importance of robust career support systems, networking opportunities, and perhaps a focus on upskilling to enhance employability.Â Those connections who indicated theyâ€™re stuck on the bench - please reach out if you need to talk!hashtag#contractorlife hashtag#onthebench

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

Then you can enter your message.  If you choose, a sample message you can cut and paste is below.  After that click submit. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.â†³ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.â†³ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.â†³ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.â†³ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.â†³ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.â€¢ â€¢ â€¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

Automation is NOT a One-Time TaskBuilding a CI/CD pipeline or an infrastructure-as-code setup is greatâ€”but itâ€™s never "done." Things change, and continuous improvement is part of the DevOps mindset.ğŸ”¹ 3. Logs & Monitoring Save LivesNo matter how good your deployment strategy is, things will break. Username: Petrina Frost, MBA (HR Mgt)Petrina Frost, MBA (HR Mgt)
Post Content:
Insights from LinkedIn Poll on Job Transition TimesI recently conducted a poll on LinkedIn to understand how long people typically expect to be between roles. The results were quite revealing and offer several insights into the current job market dynamics.A significant 37% of respondents indicated that their transition between roles was around 6 weeks. Meanwhile, 26% of participants reported a gap of around 3 months. This period could reflect the average time it takes for a thorough job search, including the application process and multiple rounds of interviews.Interestingly, 21% of respondents experienced a 6-month gap between roles. This longer duration might be attributed to more challenging job markets or specific industry requirements.Finally, 16% of those surveyed expressed feeling stuck on the bench and needing help. This emphasizes the importance of robust career support systems, networking opportunities, and perhaps a focus on upskilling to enhance employability.Â Those connections who indicated theyâ€™re stuck on the bench - please reach out if you need to talk!hashtag#contractorlife hashtag#onthebench

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:â–¶ï¸ Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. â–¶ï¸ Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms â€œcompetitive levelâ€ and â€œretention registerâ€ are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. â–¶ï¸ Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veteransâ€™ preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. â–¶ï¸ Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veteransâ€™ preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employeeâ€™s service computation date on the retention register. â–¶ï¸ Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: â€œBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure groupâ€œRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employeeâ€™s bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.â†³ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.â†³ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.â†³ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.â†³ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.â†³ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.â€¢ â€¢ â€¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

ğŸ” Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles ğŸš€In 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments ğŸ“ as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud rolesâ€”positions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:ğŸ“Œ Does this reflect the real-world work environment?ğŸ“Œ Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?ğŸ“Œ Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?ğŸ” Evidence & Trends:âœ… AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.âœ… Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.âœ… Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineeringâ€”not just coding fluency.âš ï¸ The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that donâ€™t measure real-world capabilities.---ğŸŒ The Perfect Hiring Process â€“ If We Lived in a Perfect WorldğŸ”¹ ğŸ“ Intro Chat (30 min) â€“ A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just â€œtell me about yourself.â€ğŸ”¹ ğŸ› ï¸ Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) â€“ A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.ğŸ”¹ âš¡ Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) â€“ A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!ğŸ”¹ ğŸ¤ Team Fit & Culture (30 min) â€“ A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.ğŸ”¹ ğŸš€ Decision in <1 Week â€“ Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---ğŸ› ï¸ It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? ğŸ¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ğŸ¤”In the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stackâ€”everyone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Letâ€™s break it down:ğŸ“Œ ğŸš€ Googleâ€™s Influence on Startups:ğŸ”¹ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Googleâ€”even if they donâ€™t actually need that complexity.ğŸ”¹ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Googleâ€™s work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.ğŸ”¹ Hiring & Evaluation: Googleâ€™s System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.ğŸ”¹ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesnâ€™t guarantee success.ğŸ“Œ âš–ï¸ When Does Copying Google Make Sense?âœ… If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.âœ… If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.âœ… If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.ğŸ“Œ â›” When Is It a Mistake?âŒ If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.âŒ If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.âŒ If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because theyâ€™re "the industry standard."ğŸ”¹ ğŸ’¡ The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didnâ€™t come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processesâ€”it came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?ğŸ’¬ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! ğŸ‘‡hashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship ğŸš€

Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noiseâ€”saving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Hereâ€™s how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :â€¢Â Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.â€¢Â You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.â€¢Â Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrongâ€¢Â ~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. â€¢Â Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.â€¢Â Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deployâ€¢Â Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

Username: Comox Valley Regional DistrictComox Valley Regional District
Post Content:
CVRD News: Unified Alternative Approval Process Results AnnouncedThe Comox Valley Regional District (CVRD) Unified Alternative Approval Process (AAP) has completed and results have been finalized. The deadline for responses was February 18, 2025 at 4:30pm.Less than 10% of the eligible electors signed and submitted elector response forms by the deadline for all four CVRD initiatives.In line with provincial legislation, the Corporate Officer has reviewed and certified the results. Elector response forms must be rejected when:- an elector signed more than one form (duplicates);- an elector is determined to be ineligible;- more than one non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to the same property; or - a non-resident property elector signed a form in relation to a property owned in whole or in part by a corporation.In this instance, the vast majority of rejected elector response forms were either due to duplicate forms submitted or ineligibility, as residents were outside of the defined service area.These results and the associated bylaws will be considered by the CVRD Board at their February 25, 2025 regular meeting.Full news release: https://ow.ly/7HrW50V5NXZFor more information on the AAP and to learn more about voter requirements for each initiative, visit www.comoxvalleyrd.ca/aap.

Username: Petrina Frost, MBA (HR Mgt)Petrina Frost, MBA (HR Mgt)
Post Content:
Insights from LinkedIn Poll on Job Transition TimesI recently conducted a poll on LinkedIn to understand how long people typically expect to be between roles. The results were quite revealing and offer several insights into the current job market dynamics.A significant 37% of respondents indicated that their transition between roles was around 6 weeks. Meanwhile, 26% of participants reported a gap of around 3 months. This period could reflect the average time it takes for a thorough job search, including the application process and multiple rounds of interviews.Interestingly, 21% of respondents experienced a 6-month gap between roles. This longer duration might be attributed to more challenging job markets or specific industry requirements.Finally, 16% of those surveyed expressed feeling stuck on the bench and needing help. This emphasizes the importance of robust career support systems, networking opportunities, and perhaps a focus on upskilling to enhance employability.Â Those connections who indicated theyâ€™re stuck on the bench - please reach out if you need to talk!hashtag#contractorlife hashtag#onthebench

If you can keep scrolling, itâ€™s a problem.The wave of layoffs across the U.S. isnâ€™t just their problemâ€”itâ€™s our problem. Every day, talented professionals wake up to uncertainty, not knowing how theyâ€™ll pay their bills, support their families, or take their next step.I make sure to post, comment, and share opportunities because I am blessed to be gainfully employedâ€”and I know how quickly circumstances can change. It takes only a few moments to be kind. A few moments to reshare a job post and give someone more visibility. A few moments to acknowledge someoneâ€™s struggle and remind them theyâ€™re not alone.If youâ€™ve ever needed a door opened, a referral, or just a little encouragementâ€”pay it forward. Letâ€™s show up for each other. ğŸ’™hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Layoffs hashtag#Support hashtag#Networking hashtag#KindnessMatters
